Award.AwardTitle: RUI: Detecting Gravitational Waves with Pulsars - ISM propagation delay
Award.AbstractNarration:
Dr. Dan Stinebring of Oberlin College will develop new techniques for the analysis of pulsar timing data. Pulsars are rapidly spinning neutron stars which emit beams of radio radiation. Accurate timing of detected radio pulses probes stellar physics, and can in principle detect gravitational waves produced by massive black holes in the cores of galaxies. In this project, Dr. Stinebring and his students will explore propagation effects as these radio pulses pass through interstellar gas between the pulsars and the Earth. Understanding these effects is important, since they can hamper high precision timing of pulsars by introducing random noise into the timing signals.

This research is anticipated to benefit the scientific community by improving the ability to detect gravitational waves. The analysis methods will also aid the understanding of the interstellar gas, including how it is distributed in space and how turbulence operates within it. Dr. Stinebring will provide research opportunities for undergraduate students, who will work closely with him in the process of data taking and analysis.

POR.DRECONTENT:
We are helping to expand the way astronomers study the universe. In particular, my group is part of an effort to open up "gravitational wave astronomy," which is the study of the universe through the detection and study of gravitational waves. We have good evidence that gravitational waves exist (see, e.g. the Nobel Prize in 1993 to Russell Hulse and Joseph Taylor), but they have never been directly detected. Our collaboration, called NANOGrav (see www.nanograv.org) seeks to use ultra-precise observations of pulses from radio pulsars (rotating, collapsed stars) to detect gravitational waves.

What are the sources of gravitational waves? There are many, but the ones that we are focusing on are produced by supermassive black holes (SMBHs) at the center of distant galaxies. Some of these SMBHs, which may have the mass of 100 million or even a billion Suns, should be orbiting each other with orbital periods of a few years. This makes them excellent objects to study with our array of pulsars, also known as a Pulsar Timing Array.

The NANOGrav Pulsar Timing Array uses two fantastic radio telescopes: the Arecibo radio telescope in Puerto Rico, which is the world's largest (diameter 305-meters) and most sensitive radio telescope in the world. Our other radio telescope -- the Green Bank radio Telescope -- currently operated by the National Radio Astronomy Observatory, is also a super-sensitive dish that is 100 meters in diameter and fully steerable. Furthermore, it is located in the US National Radio Quiet Zone, which greatly improves our sensitivity because of protection from human-made radio interference.

Although the science that we are doing is at a very exciting stage -- and has been recognized as such by several national committees -- both of our key telescopes are under threat of imminent "de-funding" by the National Science Foundation. We see this as regrettable since they are producing tremendously useful science at a fraction of the cost needed for other astronomical efforts, let alone the cost of anything connected with the military. However, we persevere in our efforts to do the best science possible with these instruments at the same time that we seek other funding sources to keep them open.

My group's particular research focus -- along with others in the NANOGrav and international community -- is to correct for small time delays caused by interstellar ionized gas. The radio waves from pulsars cross through this ionized gas on their way to our telescopes and are slightly delayed (by several millionths of a second) by interaction with the gas. That may sound like an incredibly small amount -- and it is -- but we need to measure the arrival of pulsar pulses to something like one one-hundredth of a microsecond (10 ns) in order to successfully detect gravitational waves from SMBHs.

During the previous grant period we made several advances that are improving our ability to detect gravitational waves. First, we studied how to most accurately measure for the largest time delay -- what astronomers call "dispersion delay" -- in our signals. We showed that there is a subtle, frequency-dependent effect that needs to be accounted for in order to achieve the most accurate pulse arrival times. We also made several studies -- over 3-6 months -- of the time variation in pulse arrival times toward several pulsars of interest. We are doing this to better characterize the "interstellar weather" toward these pulsars. In turn, that will allow us to more properly correct the signals we get from the pulsars in our Pulsar Timing Array.

As an important "broader impact"  of this research activity, about a dozen Oberlin College undergraduates have received training and opportunities to do cutting-edge science within the NANOGrav collaboration.
